contentrichtext.text: {{ref improve|date=March 2013}} [[Image:Forme of Cury title page.png|thumb|right|Title page of ''The Forme of Cury'' (18th century ed.)]] The '''''Forme of Cury''''' (Forms of Cooking, ''cury'' being from French ''[[wikt:cuire|cuire]]'') is an extensive [[recipe]] collection of the 14th century. Its authors are given as "the chief Master Cooks of [[Richard II of England|King Richard II]]". The modern name was given to it by [[Samuel Pegge]], who published an edition of it in 1791. This name has since come into usage for almost all versions of the original manuscript. Along with [[Le Viandier]], it is the best-known [[medieval]] guide to cooking. The roll was written in late [[Middle English]] (circa 1390) on [[vellum]] and details some 205 [[recipe]]s (although the exact number of recipes varies slightly between different versions). ==Sample recipe== The following is an example of a recipe taken from Pegge's 18th century edition of the roll. :'''SAWSE MADAME. XXX.''' :Take sawge. persel. ysope. and saueray. quinces. and peeres, garlek and Grapes. and fylle the gees þerwith. and sowe the hole þat no grece come out. and roost hem wel. and kepe the grece þat fallith þerof. take galytyne and grece and do in a possynet, whan the gees buth rosted ynouh; take an smyte hem on pecys. and þat tat is withinne and do it in a possynet and put þerinne wyne if it be to thyk. do þerto powdour of galyngale. powdour douce and salt and boyle the sawse and dresse þe Gees in disshes and lay þe sowe onoward. In modern English: :'''SAUCE MADAME. 30.''' :Take [[Salvia officinalis|sage]], [[parsley]], [[Hyssopus officinalis|hyssop]] and [[Savory (genus)|savoury]], [[quinces]] and [[pear]]s, [[garlic]] and [[grape]]s, and stuff the geese with them. Sew the hole so that no grease comes out, and roast them well, and keep the [[dripping]] that falls from them. Take galyntyne [sauce or jelly of meat juices] and grease and add to a [[posset]]; when the geese be roasted enough, take and smite [cut] them into pieces, and that which is within and add to a posset and put wine in it if it be too thick. Add powder of [[galingale (disambiguation)|galingale]]{{dn|date=June 2013}}, [[powder-douce]] and salt, and boil the sauce and dress the geese in dishes and put the sauce on them.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00b6vl6/ As cooked by [[Clarissa Dickson Wright]] on the [[BBC Four]] show [[Clarissa and the King's Cookbook]].</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *{{gutenberg|no=8102|name=The Forme of Cury}}, a transcription *[http://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=LcwVmHygaCoC&dq=Forme+of+Cury&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=2OyazS8KQR&sig=Sni-zAFqpEsPZRgF_IoblL-4UwI&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA72,M1 page images of the modern edition at Google Books] *[http://www.pbm.com/~lindahl/foc/ page images of the 18th century edition] *[http://www.celtnet.org.uk/recipes/forme-cury-contents.php facsimile version of the original text with modern English translation and modern redactions] *[http://www.bl.uk/learning/langlit/booksforcooks/med/pygghome/sawge.html Pygg in sawse sawge (British Library)] [[Category:Medieval cookbooks]] [[Category:Middle English literature]]
